'''Joe Pullum''' (December 25, 1905 — January 7, 1964)<ref name="eagle">{{cite book
| first1= Bob
| last1= Eagle
| first2= Eric S.
| last2= LeBlanc
| year= 2013
| title= Blues - A Regional Experience
| edition= 
| publisher= Praeger Publishers
| location= Santa Barbara
| page= 44
| isbn= 978-0313344237}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].

==Biography==
Pullum, an [[Alabama]]-born [[nightclub]] singer, was one of the more obscure blues [[celebrity|stars]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| pages= 157–158
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> He was accompanied on his few recordings by two [[pianist]]s; Rob Cooper on his earlier [[Gramophone record|discs]], and Andy Boy on his later efforts. Pullum's major success was with his self-written song, "Black Gal What Makes Your Head So Hard?" (1934).  It sold in large quantities and was [[cover version|covered]] by [[Leroy Carr]], [[Skip James]], [[Mary Johnson (singer)|Mary Johnson]], Jimmie Gordon, [[Josh White]], [[Bumble Bee Slim]], the [[Harlem Hamfats]], [[Smokey Hogg]] and [[James Crutchfield]]. His subsequent recordings did not fare as well.<ref name="russell"/><ref name="Blues">{{cite web |url=http://sundayblues.org/archives/tag/joe-pullum |title=Joe Pullum |publisher=Sundayblues.org |accessdate=January 2010}}</ref>

Pullum [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] four sessions, which yielded a total of 30 tracks, between April 1934 and February 1936.<ref name="russell"/><ref>[http://www.nme.com/artists/joe-pullum ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref> The tracks included two intended sequels to "Black Gal," but overall sales were modest. Pullum later performed on radio on the Houston station, KTLC, backed by another pianist, Preston "Peachy" Chase.<ref name="Blues"/> Pullum relocated to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] in the 1940s, and he further interpreted "Black Gal" into "My Woman", accompanied by [[Lloyd Glenn]], on Swingtime Records in 1948.<ref name="russell"/> He also reputedly recorded a [[demo (music)|demo]] with [[Specialty Records]] in 1953.<ref name="Blues"/>

Although he was a gifted songwriter, few of his contemporaries seemed able to recall him.<ref name="russell"/>

Pullum died in 1964, aged 58, and was buried in [[Houston]], [[Texas]]. All of his known recordings were collated on two [[Document Records|Document]] [[album]]s released in 1995.

==Legacy==
[[Music journalism|Music journalist]] Tony Russell wrote that "Pullum's high clear voice, drifting over the peaks and valleys of "Black Gal What Makes Your Head So Hard?", brought the shock of the new into mid-1930s blues. No one before, male or female, had sung with such feline grace. What's more, Pullum's ethereal manner hardly prepared the listener for the song's scenario of insults, smoking pistols and suicide".<ref name="russell"/>
